description: From Middle English *hake, from Old English hæca, haca (“hook, bolt, door-fastening, bar”), from Proto-West Germanic *hakō, from Proto-Germanic *hakô (“hook”), from Proto-Indo-European *keg-, *keng- (“peg, hook”).  Related to hook.

entries.meaning: (Now chiefly dialectal) A hook; a pot-hook.
(Now chiefly dialectal) A kind of weapon; a pike.
(Now chiefly dialectal) (in the plural) The draught-irons of a plough.

description: From Middle English hake, probably a shortened form (due to North Germanic influence) of English dialectal haked (“pike”). Compare Norwegian hakefisk (“trout, salmon”), Middle Low German haken (“kipper”). More at haked.

entries.meaning: One of several species of marine gadoid fishes, of the genera Phycis, Merluccius, and allies.
A drying shed, as for unburned tile.
examples: The clay is taken direct from the bank and made into brick the right temper to place direct from the Machine in the hake on the yard. [...] take the brick direct from the Machine and put them in the hake to dry.

description: Ultimately related to the root of hook. Compare Dutch haken (“to hanker”).

verbs.description: hake (third-person singular simple present hakes, present participle haking, simple past and past participle haked)
